name: Mount Rainier National Park
description: Ascending to 14,410 feet above sea level, Mount Rainier stands as an icon in the Washington landscape. An active volcano, Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the contiguous U.S.A., spawning five major rivers. Subalpine wildflower meadows ring the icy volcano while ancient forest cloaks Mount Rainier’s lower slopes. Wildlife abounds in the park’s ecosystems. A lifetime of discovery awaits.
shortDescription: Ascending to 14,410 feet above sea level, Mount Rainier stands as an icon in the Washington landscape. An active volcano, Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the contiguous U.S.A., spawning fi...

operatingHours.description: Mount Rainier National Park is open all year. Visitation peaks in July and August with warmer weather and  blooming wildflowers. In spring and autumn, weather determines the availability of facilities and roads. During winter months a number of roads, facilities, and entrances close for the season.

fees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle
fees.description: Grants unlimited entry for one vehicle and passengers for seven consecutive days. Vehicle must be private, noncommercial, and with a seating capacity of 15 or less.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Walk-up or single bicycle fee. Grants unlimited entry for seven consecutive days.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 7 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan
fees.description: These fees are charged only to commercial organizations, such as tour companies. This fee is determined by the seating capacity of the vehicle. For sedan with 1 to 6 seats, the fee is $30 + $15 per client.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van
fees.description: These fees are charged only to commercial organizations, such as tour companies. This fee is determined by the seating capacity of the vehicle.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description: These fees are charged only to commercial organizations, such as tour companies. This fee is determined by the seating capacity of the vehicle.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description: These fees are charged only to commercial organizations, such as tour companies. This fee is determined by the seating capacity of the vehicle. NOTE: There are no current road restrictions for unmodified motor coaches of the standard length in the park. However, be aware that roads in the park are steep, narrow, and winding. In particular, it is recommended that RVs and vehicles with trailers longer than 25 feet LOA not travel up the Sunrise Road beyond the White River Campground intersection.

climate.weatherDescription: Weather patterns at Mount Rainier are strongly influenced by the Pacific Ocean and elevation. The climate is generally cool and rainy, with summer highs in the 60s and 70s. While July and August are the sunniest months of the year, rain is very likely in spring, fall, and winter. Visitors should be aware that mountain weather is very changeable. In the higher elevations, like Paradise, winter can last from November to May with many feet of snow on the ground.

images.title: Silver Forest Sunset
images.altText: A purple and pink streaked sky over a mountain peak and forested valley.
images.caption: The Silver Forest Trail at Sunrise features spectacular views of Mount Rainier and the White River valley.

images.title: Climbing Mount Rainier
images.altText: Climber on glacier steps downward with icy crags in background.
images.caption: Summiting Mount Rainier involves climbing a volcano, scaling glaciers, dealing with high elevations and much more. Almost 10,000 people a year attempt to summit.

images.title: Giants of the Old-Growth Forest
images.altText: Towering cedars and douglas-firs reach skyward while a beam of sun breaks through the canopy.
images.caption: With some of the few remaining old-growth forests in the Cascade Mountains, Mount Rainier National Park protects native plants great and small in places like the Grove of the Patriarchs.

images.title: Marmot in Morning Dew
images.altText: A hoary marmot with white frosted fur rests on a rock beside white flowers in a meadow.
images.caption: From small amphibians and hoary marmots to the black bears and elk, many animals call the wild places of Mount Rainier home.

images.title: Kids Hiking Through Wildflower Meadow
images.altText: Two children hike on trail through wildflower meadow with Mount Rainier above them.
images.caption: Enjoying the outdoors through recreation is a big part of many visitors' experiences.

images.title: Mount Rainier at sunset
images.altText: Sunset paints the glaciers of Mount Rainier in pink and gold.
images.caption: Every scenic overlook shows a different side of Mount Rainier. Viewed from Gobblers Knob Lookout at sunset, the glaciers covering the mountain turn pink and gold.

images.title: National Park Inn in Winter
images.altText: The historic National Park Inn covered in a foot of snow.
images.caption: For thousands of years, people have traveled up to, over, and around Mount Rainier. Today the park strives to preserve this history while providing a chance for new generations to find their own adventures.

images.title: Wildflower Meadow Along the Wonderland Trail
images.altText: Purple lupine and white bistort bloom in a meadow alongside a sign for the Wonderland Trail.
images.caption: Both the Wonderland Trail and subalpine meadows encircle Mount Rainier. Summertime blooms splatter the hillsides with color.

images.title: Mount Rainier from Aurora Lake
images.altText: A glaciated mountain framed by forested hillsides reflects in a still mountain lake.
images.caption: Aurora Lake in Klapatche Park on the west side of Mount Rainier.
